{{Multiple issues| {{autobiography|date=April 2014}} {{advert|date=April 2014}} }} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Tania de Jong
{{small|{{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM}}}} | alt = | caption = Tania de Jong AM | birth name = | background = solo_singer | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Arnhem]], [[The Netherlands]] | death_date = | origin = [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] | instrument = Voice (soprano) | genre = | occupation = [[Soprano]]; [[social entrepreneur]] | years_active = 1995{{spaced endash}}''present'' | label = Pot Pourri | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://www.taniadejong.com}} }} '''Tania Karen de Jong''', {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM}},{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1138648&search_type=quick&showInd=true|title=Search: de JONG, Tania Karen|work=It's an Honour|publisher=[[Australian Government]]|date=9 June 2008|accessdate=14 March 2015}} is an Australian [[soprano]], [[social entrepreneur]], business woman, creative innovation catalyst{{clarify|date=May 2018}} and [[motivational speaker]]. She is the co-founder and artistic director of [[entertainment]] and event company Music Theatre Australia - MTA Entertainment and Events. She is also the founder and a performer in the musical group [[Pot-Pourri (group)|Pot-Pourri]] which has released seven albums, and she has founded several social enterprises. De Jong has performed with the Victoria State Opera and has performed in over 40 countries. De Jong is working on a number of creative projects and released her first solo album ''Heaven on Earth'' in 2015 and released her new album ''Flying Free ''in 2017. She has sung in many languages, including English, Spanish, French, Latin, German, Italian, Russian, Mandarin Chinese, Japanese and Hebrew. ==Background, early life and education== De Jong was born in [[Arnhem]], [[The Netherlands]], to her Dutch father and Austrian mother; and the family moved to [[Melbourne, Victoria|Melbourne]], Australia, when de Jong was one year-old.{{cite web|url=http://dutchaustralian.com/meet-tania-de-jong/|title=Meet Tania de Jong|work=Dutch Australian |author=Veldman-Tentori, Renee|date=20 April 2012|accessdate=14 March 2015}} Her grandfather, Karl Duldig, a Polish refugee who escaped the Holocaust, was a Vienna-trained sculptor. Her grandmother, [[Slawa Duldig]] also trained as a sculptor in Vienna and invented the world's first modern folding umbrella.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/soprano-on-a-mission-20140313-34o35.html|title=Soprano on a mission|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|author=Evans, Kathy|date=15 March 2014|accessdate=14 March 2015}} Their home in Melbourne's {{VICcity|Malvern East}} now operates as a museum.{{cite web|url=http://www.duldig.org.au/|title=The Duldig Studio|publisher=|work=|date=|accessdate=}} De Jong's mother was a Dutch national tennis champion, a [[Fed Cup|Federation Cup]] player for Australia and a quarter-finalist at [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]. Aged 14, de Jong was advised by a friend not to bother with singing lessons. She finally got up the courage to audition for the chorus of her school's performance of ''[[Oklahoma (musical)|Oklahoma]]'' at age 17 and was cast in the lead role.{{cite news|url=http://www.theweeklyreviewbayside.com.au/story/1792501/interview-one-voice-many-stories/?nav=Y2F0X2lkLzE0|title=One Voice, Many Stories|author=Wilmoth, Peter|work=The Weekly Review|date=12 November 2013|accessdate=14 March 2015}} Interviewed in 2009, she recalled: {{quotation|''"I was the kid who said my favourite pop group was Beethoven."''|Tania de Jong, interviewed in ''[[The Age]]'' in 2009.}} De Jong graduated from the [[University of Melbourne]] with a Bachelor of Law (Honours) and from the [[Victorian College of the Arts]] with a Graduate Diploma in Opera and Music Theatre and a Postgraduate Diploma in Music (Opera and Voice). She also attended college in the USA on a tennis scholarship. ==Not-for-profit activities== In 1999, de Jong created [https://www.songroom.org.au/ The Song Room], a not-for-profit organisation dedicated to providing access to music and arts programs in Australian schools and communities. Since 2001, The Song Room has reached over 300,000 disadvantaged children, enhancing their education, personal development and community involvement and engaging them in a passion for creativity and lifelong learning.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/tania-de-jong-mixes-a-love-of-singing-with-management/story-e6frg8zx-1225822641826|title=Tania de Jong Mixes a love of singing with management|work=[[The Australian]]|author=Kaplan, Morris|date=23 January 2010|accessdate=14 March 2015}} In November 2008, she founded [https://www.creativityaustralia.org.au/ Creativity Australia], a non-profit organisation that delivers programs for employers that are designed to unlock the creativity of their staff and encourage teamwork through workplace choirs and other artistic endeavours.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/arts/with-a-song-in-her-briefcase/2009/03/08/1236447043604.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1|title=With a song in her briefcase|work=[[The Age]]|author=Edwards, Lorna|date=9 March 2009|accessdate=14 March 2015}}{{Cite journal|last=Tarrant|first=Deborah|date=2011|title=Introducing, on lead vocals|url=http://www.creativityaustralia.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/brightideas-qantas-mag-sept-2011.pdf|journal=Qantas Magazine|volume=September|pages=163–165|via=}} Diversity and well-being are the focus of the With One Voice choir program.{{Cite news|url=https://www.meldmagazine.com.au/2013/11/tedxmelbourne-tania-de-jong/|title=TEDxMelbourne: Social entrepreneur and soprano singer Tania de Jong|date=2013-11-29|work=Meld Magazine - Australia's international student news website|access-date=2018-07-25|language=en-AU}} ==Discography== *1995: ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WIqsMpaTHY0&list=PL63CD2057C3AADCA3 Rhythm of Life]'' - Pot-Pourri *1997: ''Something Familiar!, Something Peculiar'' - Pot-Pourri *1999: ''[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3DCB65DFC561745E This is the Moment]'' - Pot-Pourri *2001: ''[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBECA38204A117C49 Friends for Life]'' - Pot-Pourri *2003: ''[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL42941B8BFEA739DE Chanson d'Amour]'' - Pot-Pourri *2004: ''Soundsations'' - Dorje and Diva (Tania de Jong & Chris Walker) *2006: ''[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAF467CBEC9083389 Nella Fantasia]'' - Pot-Pourri *2012: ''[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLC51CAFA08ADBA833 Silver]'' - Pot-Pourri *2015: ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=57z2hPrVzG0&list=OLAK5uy_kVEiwjvnIktB5fsj32zVyLza1zcAC5aXg Heaven on Earth]'' - Tania de Jong *2017: ''[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbFcm1heNMZQd7V82JxaA9Q Flying Free]'' - Tania de Jong ==Recognition== In 2006 de Jong received the Ernst and Young Australian Social Entrepreneur of the Year Award for her work with The Song Room charity. De Jong's other awards include the "Outstanding Individual Contribution to Australian Culture" (1998) and the Accessibility Award in The Melbourne Awards (2005). She was a finalist in the Telstra Business Women’s Awards (2001) and studied overseas on a Churchill Fellowship in (1996). She has recently been inducted into the AGSE Entrepreneurs Hall of Fame at Swinburne University. De Jong was named Brainlink Woman of Achievement 2009. She was a runner-up in the Westpac Community Leader Awards in 2013.http://www.taniadejong.com/news/finalist-in-the-westpac-community-leaders-awards/ Creativity Australia was named one of Australia’s top social innovations in Anthill’s Smart 100 for the second year in a row. De Jong was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia in 2008 for service to the arts as a performer and entrepreneur and through the establishment and development of music and arts enrichment programs for schools and communities. She was named in ''The Australian Financial Review'' 100 Women of Influence awards in the Arts, Culture and Sport category.{{Cite news|url=https://www.afr.com/brand/100women/women-of-influence-2018-winner-fights-for-recognition-of-indigenous-australians-20181015-h16npc|title=Women of Influence 2018 winner fights for recognition of Indigenous Australians|last=Patten|first=Sally|date=2018-10-17|work=Australian Financial Review|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en-US}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:De Jong, Tania}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:Australian people of Polish descent]] [[Category:Australian sopranos]] [[Category:Melbourne Law School alumni]] [[Category:Victorian College of the Arts alumni]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.text:
'''Virtual CFO''' (or '''vCFO''' for short) stands for virtual [[chief financial officer]]. A virtual CFO is an outsourced service provider offering high skill assistance in financial requirements of an organization, just like a chief financial officer does for large organizations.<ref name="IndiaTimes">[http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-12-19/news/45377498_1_smes-clients-startups "Virtual CFO services gaining traction in NCR region"] in ''The Economic Times''</ref> A virtual CFO may be a single person or an entity.
== Target market ==
The mushrooming of the startup ecosystem has generated specialized service providers which fit the requirement of startups. Virtual CFO is one such specialized service provider. Startups normally do not have the resources to hire a full-time CFO.<ref name="TECCPV">[https://books.google.com/books?id=747tKaSdtgkC&pg=PA394&dq=virtual+cfo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zRj6UuypFc2nrgeshIHgCg&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=virtual%20cfo&f=false ''Technology Entrepreneurship: Creating, Capturing, and Protecting Value''] by Thomas N. Duening, Robert A. Hisrich, Michael A. Lechter</ref> "There have been studies claiming that among the top issues faced by Indian startup CEOs are hiring financial and legal experts," according to a virtual CFO.<ref name="IndiaTimes"/> Startups like to keep fixed costs low and having outsourced service provider provides them the flexibility of choosing services as and when required. A Virtual CFO provides strategic, value add services to a startup which cannot be provided by an accountant.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=z5sLg7JGu_IC&pg=PA34&dq=virtual+cfo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zRj6UuypFc2nrgeshIHgCg&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=virtual%20cfo&f=false ''Business Owner's Handbook: The Ultimate Small Business Book -- Focus on Management of Money and Leadership to Increase Company Value''] By Marty Koenig and Keith McAslan</ref> In the United States, VCFO services are typically used by small to medium-businesses with annual sales in excess of $1 million.<ref>[http://www.fintelligent.com/ Fintelligent]</ref>
In Singapore, the market is mainly served by [http://supercfo.com/ SuperCFO], [https://www.cfocentre.com.sg/ CFOCentre] and [https://www.excide.co Excide]. SuperCFO and CFOCentre focus on experienced finance individuals that are parachuted into the company. On the other hand, [https://www.excide.co/ Excide] provides virtual CFO services with emphasis on their all-rounded team and technology capabilities. While there are many other accounting firms adopting the term, "[http://hirevirtualcfo.com/ Virtual CFO] ", most of them are merely bookkeeping services.
== Services offered ==
The primary role of a [[chief financial officer]] in any organization is to oversee the financial planning, maintain and report on the financial activities and manage [[financial risk]] of the business. A virtual CFO provides the same services but since the common clientele of a Virtual CFO are small businesses and startups, there are certain more services that are expected of them. Services offered by a Virtual CFO often follow the Financial pyramid of needs. In the basic level, a Virtual CFO is expected to be the bookkeeper of the client and has to take responsibility for the accuracy of the account books and interpret the financial information from the accounting data to the client. They make take responsibility for executing or overseeing the reporting process. On the more strategic side, they are the financial and strategic sparring partner from the CEO. Additionally, they are also responsible for suggesting measures to control expenditure and acquire capital at low cost.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffthomson/2013/02/14/signs-a-small-business-needs-a-cfo/ 'Signs a Small Business Needs a CFO'] in ''Forbes''</ref>
== Practice ==
Small companies may need a controller on a weekly or fortnightly basis. Virtual CFOs also offer one-time help with strategic transactions, financial processes, business plans and budgeting.
In the USA, Virtual CFOs earn between $55 and $250 an hour,<ref name="TECCPV"/> as per their level of expertise. Clients are invoiced on an hourly or monthly rate depending on the nature of service. Most firms provide tailor-made services and the service charges vary from client to client<ref name="IndiaTimes"/> This practice is gaining ground in India, with a thriving start-up and SME culture in the country. This sector has discovered new virtual CFO companies in the last three to four years, mainly because the start-ups want to focus in their core areas, leaving the technical job to technical people.<ref>[http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-12-19/news/45377498_1_smes-clients-startups ''The Economic Times'']</ref>
However, this practice should be differentiated from finance outsourcing. Finance outsourcing is commonly understood to indicate a trans-national outsourcing process, in which financial management of companies is generally outsourced from Western countries to low-wage group countries, like India, South Africa, Brazil, etc.
== Trademark ==
virtualcfo is a registered trademark of VirtualCFO, Inc. and vcfo Holdings, Inc. in the United States and other countries.<ref>https://www.vcfo.com/legal</ref> However, as a generic term "virtual cfo" is used by many finance outsourcing firms throughout the world.
== Professional qualifications ==
There is currently no official requirement as to the qualifications that a virtual CFO should hold. However, it is generally expected for a virtual CFO to have finance related university degree, professional accountancy qualification and sufficient relevant experience.
In addition, virtual CFOs can obtain the Qualified Cloud CFO (QCCFO) professional certification provided by the International Association of Qualified Cloud Accountants (IAQCA)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iaqca.com/qccfo/ |title=Qualified Cloud CFO (QCCFO) certification}} - official website of the certification</ref> that is specifically focused on the knowledge that financial professionals need to deliver their services within the Internet and Cloud environment.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://blog.tempcfo.com/outsource-accounting/ Benefits of Outsourcing CFO Services] * [https://www.abel-finance.com/value-virtual-cfo/ The value of a Virtual CFO]
[[Category:Chief financial officers]] [[Category:Management occupations]] [[Category:Outsourcing]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use British English|date=January 2017}} '''William Denholm Barnetson, Baron Barnetson''' (born 21 March 1917, [[Edinburgh]] – 12 March 1981, [[Westminster]], London) was a newspaper proprietor and television executive.<ref name = "ODNB">[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/30793 Edward Pickering: ''Barnetson, William Denholm, Baron Barnetson (1917–1981)'' Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 20 June 2012]</ref>
==Early life and education== He was educated at the [[Royal High School, Edinburgh|Royal High School]], Edinburgh, and [[Edinburgh University]]. Whilst at university aged 19 he set himself up as a freelance reporter on the [[Spanish Civil War]].<ref name = "ODNB"/> Returning to university in 1940 he took his [[Master of Arts|MA]].
==War service== During [[World War II]] he served as a [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] in the [[Anti-Aircraft Command]], a part of the army. After the war he was set the task of reorganising German newspaper and publishing industries in the British occupation zone of Germany. He was responsible for the launch of [[Die Welt]] choosing [[Axel Springer]] as its publisher.<ref name = "ODNB"/>
==Career== Returning to Edinburgh from 1948-1961 he worked for the [[Edinburgh Evening News]] eventually becoming General Manager.
In 1962 he was recruited by [[Harley Drayton]] as director of [[United Newspapers]] becoming chairman in 1966. Within three years he had doubled the size of United acquiring of [[Yorkshire Post Newspapers]] and [[Punch (magazine)|Punch]] magazine.<ref name = "ODNB"/>
He had directorships of several other organisations and was chairman of [[Reuters]] from 1968–79 during which time its turnover rose from £6m to £73m. From 1979 he was chairman of [[Thames Television]]. <ref>Matthew H.C.G., editor, Dictionary of National Biography on CD-ROM (Oxford, U.K.: Oxford University Press, 1995) cited at http://www.thepeerage.com/e9200.htm</ref>
==Personal life== He was the son of William Barnetson and Isabella "Ella" Grigor Moir. In July 1940 he married Joan Fairley Davidson, daughter of William Fairley Davidson and Agustina Bjarnarson.<ref name = "Peerage"/> They had a son and three daughters.
Barnetson was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in 1972<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=45595 |date=10 February 1972 |page=1686}}</ref> and created a [[life peer]] on 14 July 1975 as '''Baron Barnetson''', of [[Crowborough]] in the County of [[East Sussex]].<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=46634 |date=17 July 1975 |page=9083}}</ref><ref name = "Peerage">{{cite web |url=http://thepeerage.com/p15172.htm#i151713 |work=The Peerage |title=William Denholm Barnetson, Baron Barnetson |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2012 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barnetson, William Denholm}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:People educated at the Royal High School, Edinburgh]] [[Category:People from Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:Scottish television executives]] [[Category:British newspaper executives]]

{{For|William Henry Fitzhugh Lee's cousin, also a Civil War officer and politician|Fitzhugh Lee}} {{More citations needed|date=May 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox congressman | name = William Henry Fitzhugh Lee | image name = WHF Lee LOC.jpg | caption = | imagesize = 240px | birth_date = {{birth date|1837|5|31|mf=y}} | birth_place =[[Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial|Arlington House]], [[Virginia]] | death_date ={{death date and age|1891|10|15|1837|5|31|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Alexandria, Virginia|Alexandria]], Virginia | resting_place = | state = [[Virginia]] | district = [[Virginia's 8th congressional district|8th]] | term_start = March 4, 1887 | term_end = October 15, 1891 | preceded = [[John S. Barbour, Jr.]] | succeeded = [[Elisha E. Meredith]] | order2= |office2 = Member of the [[Senate of Virginia|Virginia Senate]]
for [[Loudoun County, Virginia|Loudoun]], [[Alexandria County, Virginia|Alexandria]],
[[Fairfax County, Virginia|Fairfax]], and [[Prince William County, Virginia|Prince William]] | term_start2 = December 1, 1875 | term_end2 = December 3, 1879 | preceded2 = | succeeded2 = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = Charlotte Wickham
Mary Tabb Bolling | children = 4 | parents = [[Robert E. Lee]]
[[Mary Anna Custis Lee|Mary Anna Custis]] | religion = | residence= | allegiance ={{flag|United States|1851}}
{{flag|Confederate States}} | branch ={{army|USA}}
{{army|CSA}} | serviceyears = 1857–1859 (USA)
1861–1865 (CSA) | rank = [[File:Union army 2nd lt rank insignia.jpg|35px]] [[Second Lieutenant]] (USA)
[[File:Confederate States of America General-collar.svg|35px]] [[Major General (CSA)]] | commands = {{flagdeco|Virginia|1861}} [[9th Virginia Cavalry]] | unit = | battles = [[American Civil War]] | awards = | alma_mater= [[Harvard University]] }} '''William Henry Fitzhugh Lee''' (May 31, 1837 – October 15, 1891), known as '''Rooney Lee''' (often spelled "Roony" among friends and family) or '''W.H.F. Lee''', was the second son of General [[Robert E. Lee]] and [[Mary Anna Custis Lee|Mary Anna Custis]]. He was a planter, a [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] [[cavalry]] [[General officer|General]] in the [[American Civil War]], and later a [[United States House of Representatives|Congressman]] from [[Virginia]].{{Cite web|title = William Henry Fitzhugh "Rooney" Lee - Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial (U.S. National Park Service)|url = http://www.nps.gov/arho/learn/historyculture/william-lee.htm|website = www.nps.gov|accessdate = 2015-11-14}} ==Early life== Lee was born at [[Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial|Arlington House]] in [[Arlington, Virginia]], and named for William Henry Fitzhugh, his mother's uncle. At an early age, his father began to call him Rooney; what prompted him to use this nickname is not known, but it stuck as a way to differentiate him from his cousin [[Fitzhugh Lee]].{{cite book |last=Daughtry |first=Mary Bandy |date=2002 |title=Gray Cavalier: The Life and Wars of General W.H.F. "Rooney" Lee |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4_yQTema8jIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=William+Henry+Fitzhugh+Lee+rooney&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDleSYu83MAhXMOz4KHctEAxcQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=William%20Henry%20Fitzhugh%20Lee%20rooney&f=false |location=Cambridge, MA |publisher=Da Capo Press |pages=1–2 |isbn=978-0-306-81173-9}} Rooney Lee attended [[Harvard University]], where he befriended [[Henry Adams]], who wrote about his relationship with Lee in chapter four of his autobiography, ''[[The Education of Henry Adams]].'' [[File:Robert E Lee 1845.jpg|thumb|left|170px|Rooney Lee, about 8 years old, with his father Robert E. Lee]] Lee followed in his father's footsteps after graduation, entering the [[United States Army]] in 1857 as a [[second lieutenant#United States|second lieutenant]]. He served with the [[6th U.S. Infantry]] under [[Albert Sidney Johnston]], and participated in the [[Utah War]] against the [[Mormons]]. In 1859, he resigned from the U.S. Army to operate his [[White House Plantation]], on the south shore of the [[Pamunkey River]], in [[New Kent County, Virginia]]. ==Civil War== With the outbreak of the Civil War, Lee was commissioned as a [[Captain (land and air)|captain]] in the Confederate Army cavalry and was soon promoted to major. He initially served as a cavalry commander for [[Brigadier General (CSA)|Brig. Gen.]] [[William Loring]] in the mountains of western Virginia during his father's [[Western Virginia Campaign]]. Loring's forces were transferred to the lower Shenandoah Valley and the command of [[Stonewall Jackson]] in late 1861, and occupied the town of [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]] in early 1862. Lee was soon after assigned to the command of [[Major General (CSA)|Maj. Gen.]] [[J.E.B. Stuart]], who was leading the cavalry forces for [[Joseph E. Johnston]]'s Army of Northern Virginia, in the [[Peninsula Campaign]]. After joining Stuart, Rooney Lee's regiment participated in Stuart's first ride-around the Union army, as well as the subsequent [[Seven Days Battles]] around Richmond. During this time, Rooney's nearby White House plantation was burned to the ground, and his son Robert died of typhoid fever. During the [[Northern Virginia Campaign]], Rooney played a leading role in Stuart's well-crafted attack on General John Pope's supply base at Catlett's Station on August 22, 1862, capturing a paymaster's safe full of Yankee greenbacks.https://www.civilwarwomenblog.com/charlotte-lee/ His cavalry regiment was assigned to the brigade of Brig. Gen. [[Fitzhugh Lee]], his cousin, for the [[Maryland Campaign]]. Following the [[Battle of South Mountain]], Lee was knocked unconscious after a horse fell from under him, and was unable to participate in the [[Battle of Antietam]].https://www.civilwarwomenblog.com/charlotte-lee/ Upon his recovery, he temporarily commanded Fitzhugh Lee's cavalry brigade in Stuart's [[Chambersburg Raid]]; his conduct earning him promotion to Brigadier General. He then commanded the 3rd Brigade of Stuart's Cavalry Division at the Battles of [[Battle of Fredericksburg|Fredericksburg]] mere weeks after the death of his infant daughter.https://www.civilwarwomenblog.com/charlotte-lee/ During the [[Battle of Chancellorsville]] the following year, Lee was detached from Stuart's cavalry to defend against [[Stoneman's 1863 Raid]]. At the beginning of the [[Gettysburg Campaign]], Lee was shot in the thigh during combat at [[Battle of Brandy Station|Brandy Station]]. He spent the next two weeks recovering at [[Hickory Hill (Ashland, Virginia)|Hickory Hill]], Virginia, before being captured by Union forces. As a [[prisoner of war]], he was sent to [[Fort Monroe]] for several months, before being shipped to [[New_York_(state)|New York]], where he was held until returned to the Confederate Army on February 25, 1864, in exchange for Union Brig. Gen. [[Neal S. Dow]]. In April 1864, Lee was promoted to [[Major General (CSA)|major general]] and commanded a [[division (military)|division]] in the Cavalry Corps during the battles of [[Battle of the Wilderness|The Wilderness]]; [[Battle of Todd's Tavern|Todd's Tavern]]; [[Battle of Spotsylvania Court House|Spotsylvania Court House]]; and [[Battle of North Anna|North Anna]] in the [[Overland Campaign]]. With the death of Jeb Stuart, Rooney Lee's role increased. Lee's cavalry division patrolled the extreme right of the Confederate lines during the [[Siege of Petersburg]], defending against the [[Wilson-Kautz Raid]] at [[Battle of Staunton River Bridge|Staunton River Bridge]], [[Battle of Sappony Church|Sappony Church]] and [[First Battle of Ream's Station|First Ream's Station]]. His division was then sent north to briefly aid in the defense of Richmond at the [[Second Battle of Deep Bottom]], before supporting General [[Wade Hampton III]]'s [[Beefsteak Raid]], and then returning to Petersburg for the [[Battle of Boydton Plank Road]]. By last year of the war, Rooney Lee had risen to second-in-command of the Confederate cavalry in Virginia; General Hampton having been transferred to South Carolina to raise troops, and Lee's cousin, Fitzhugh, promoted to overall command. Lee's cavalry division screened the Confederate evacuation of Petersburg, notably at the [[Battle of Namozine Church]] during the [[Appomattox Campaign]]. He surrendered along with his father at [[Appomattox Court House National Historical Park|Appomattox Court House]] with only 300 officers and men, one-tenth the size of the command during the Petersburg Campaign.https://www.civilwarwomenblog.com/charlotte-lee/ ==Postbellum career== Lee returned to White House Plantation and planting after the war. Nearby, his younger brother [[Robert E. Lee, Jr.|Rob]] lived at Romancoke Plantation across the river in [[King William County, Virginia|King William County]]. After their mother died in 1873, Rooney inherited [[Ravensworth (plantation)|Ravensworth Plantation]], the old Fitzhugh family property (near present-day [[Springfield, Virginia|Springfield]]) in [[Fairfax County, Virginia|Fairfax County]] with {{convert|563|acre|km2}} of land. He moved there with his family from White House. In 1875 Rooney was elected to the [[Virginia Senate]], serving until 1878. He was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 1887. He served in the House until his death at Ravensworth in 1891. He is interred in the [[Lee Chapel]] at [[Washington and Lee University]] in [[Lexington, Virginia]], with his parents and siblings. ==Marriage and family== Lee married twice, first in 1859 to Charlotte Georgiana Wickham, daughter of George and Charlotte Carter Wickham and a descendant of the attorney [[John Wickham (1763)|John Wickham]] and his wife. They had two children, Robert Edward Lee, born March 11, 1860 and died June 30, 1862 and Charlotte Carter Lee, born October 19, 1862 and died December 6, 1862. Charlotte Carter Wickham Lee died December 26, 1863. On November 28, 1867, he married Mary Tabb Bolling. They had two sons, who both lived to adulthood: Robert Edward Lee III, born February 11, 1869 at Petersburg, and George Bolling Lee, born August 30, 1872 at Lexington. Lee's mother, Mary Anna Randolph Custis, was the only surviving child of [[George Washington Parke Custis]] and [[Mary Lee Fitzhugh Custis|Mary Lee Fitzhugh]]. George was the grandson of [[Martha Washington|Martha Dandridge]] and step-grandson of President [[George Washington]]. Lee was also a descendant of [[Charles II of England]] through [[Charlotte Lee, Lady Baltimore|Lady Charlotte Lee]] (granddaughter of [[Barbara Palmer, 1st Duchess of Cleveland|Barbara Villiers]]), who married [[Benedict Calvert, 4th Baron Baltimore|the 4th Baron Baltimore]], and possibly, a descendant of [[George I of Great Britain|George I]], through [[Benedict Swingate Calvert]] (grandson of Lady Charlotte Lee), the illegitimate son of [[Charles Calvert, 5th Baron Baltimore|5th Baron Baltimore]] and of an unknown mother, who was supposed to be [[Melusina von der Schulenburg, Countess of Walsingham|Melusina von der Schulenburg]], illegitimate daughter of the King. {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1.
